name: Curly-leaf Pondweed

Identifying Characteristics: Stems: branched, up to 90cm long, somewhat flattened
Leaves: green to yellowish lance-shaped, toothed margin, wavy edges, no petiole, distinct venation pattern
Flowers: early summer, small tightly arranged at end of slender stalk (7cm)
Fruits/Seeds: prominent cone-shaped beak and bumpy crown-like ridge
Other: stem slightly flattened, plants break up by mid-July
Biology: Reproduction by seed does occur but the importance to the plant's propogation is unknown
Habitat: Still or flowing waters – lakes, ponds, rivers, streams
Extremely well adapted – can survive where other aquatic plants do not: shaded, disturbed, polluted or turbid waters
Range: Northeast US Range: Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Vermont, Connecticut, New York, Rhode Island

tags: plants with blade-shaped leaves on stems
